introduction.p: This activity builds on your work in Preview Activity, using the same function f as given by the graph that is repeated in the following figure>. Assume that f(2) = -2.5.

statement.p: At which values of a does \lim_{x \to a} f(x) not exist?

hint.p: Consider the left- and right-hand limits at each value.

solution.p: \lim_{x \to a} f(x) does not exist at a = -2 since \lim_{x \to -2^-} f(x) = 2 \ne -1 = \lim_{x \to -2^+} and \lim_{x \to a} f(x) does not exist at a = +2 since \lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x) does not exist due to the infinitely oscillatory behavior of f.

statement.p: At which values of a is f(a) not defined?

hint.p: Carefully examine places on the graph where there's an open circle.

solution.p: The only point at which f is not defined is at a = 3.

statement.p: At which values of a does f have a limit, but \lim_{x \to a} f(x) \ne f(a)?

hint.p: Are there locations on the graph where the function has a limit but there's a hole in the graph?

solution.p: At a = -1, note that \lim_{x \to -1} f(x) exists (and appears to have value approximately -3.25), but f(-1) = 1, and thus \lim_{x \to -1} f(x) \ne f(-1). At a = 3, \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = -2.5, but f(3) is not defined, so the limit exists but does not equal the function value.

statement.p: State all values of a for which f is not continuous at x = a.

Which condition is stronger, and hence implies the other: f has a limit at x = a or f is continuous at x = a? Explain, and hence complete the following sentence: If f at x = a, then f at x = a, where you complete the blanks with has a limit and is continuous, using each phrase once.

hint.p: Note that the definition of being continuous requires the limit to exist.

p.q: If fis continuous at x = a, then fhas a limit at x = a.

solution.p: If fis continuous at x = a, then fhas a limit at x = a, since one of the defining properties of being continuous at x = a is that the function has a limit at that input value. This shows that being continuous is a stronger condition than having a limit.
